com.gl.vn.me.ko.pies.base.main

Interface App

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Runnable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    CommonApp, EchoApplication, InitiatorApplication, ProxyApplication

    @Singleton
public interface App
extends Runnable
    Represents refined Application logic, that is logic without processing of command-line arguments and some other routines that need to be done before the pure Application logic can be executed.

    Implementation of this interface is located by the Main class via ServiceLoader, and therefore implementation of the App MUST be public, MUST have a public constructor without parameters, and a provider-configuration file MUST be available as specified in the ServiceLoader documentation. There MUST be exactly one published implementation of App. The described constructor MUST NOT be called directly by any Application code.

    The Main class will invoke method run() on the object constructed via the mentioned constructor. Note that there is a guarantee that only one instance of the class that implements App will be created and the run() method will be called only once.

    Implementation example: 

    
 public final class HelloWorld implements App {
  private static final Logger LOGGER = LoggerFactory.getLogger(HelloWorld.class);

  private final ApplicationConfig applicationConfig;

  public HelloWorld() {
        final Injector injector = GuiceLocator.createInjector("com.gl.vn.me.ko.pies.base.main");
        applicationConfig = injector.getInstance(ApplicationConfig.class);
  }

   @Override
  public final void run() {
        LOGGER.info("Hello World! I'm running in the {} stage", applicationConfig.getStage());
  }
 }
    See Also:
    Main.main(String[])

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void run()
      Method that contains Application logic.

    • Method Detail

      • run

        void run()
        Method that contains Application logic. This method is invoked by the Main class. After return from this method JVM will be shut down by using System.exit(int) method, so if there are any threads started by the method (including those started indirectly) that require graceful shutdown, the method SHOULD take care of them.
        Specified by:
        run in interface Runnable
